definitions: break open or apart suddenly and violently from internal pressure
move somewhere suddenly or dramatically with great energy or emotion
examples: The water pipe burst during the freezing night
The balloon burst when it touched the sharp branch
She burst into the room with exciting news
The children burst out laughing at the funny joke

definitions: put something in the ground and cover it with earth
hide or conceal something so it cannot be seen or found easily
examples: They decided to bury their pet in the backyard
Pirates used to bury treasure on remote islands
She buried her face in her hands and cried
The report was buried under piles of other documents

definitions: grow or spread out thickly like a bush or shrub plant
examples: Her hair bushed out in the humid weather
The plant will bush nicely if you trim it regularly

definitions: perform music or entertainment in the street for voluntary donations from passersby
examples: Many musicians busk in the subway stations for tips
She learned to busk with her guitar during college

definitions: break damage or make something stop working properly
arrest someone or raid a place as part of police action
examples: He accidentally bust the lock trying to force it open
The old television finally bust after years of use
Police bust the illegal gambling ring last night
They got bust for selling counterfeit goods

definitions: move around in a busy energetic way doing many things quickly
examples: Servers bustled around the crowded restaurant during dinner rush
She bustled about the kitchen preparing the holiday meal

definitions: keep yourself or someone else actively engaged in doing something
examples: She busied herself with household chores to avoid worrying
The teacher busied the students with a challenging project

definitions: kill and cut up animals for meat in a professional way
do something very badly ruining it through lack of skill
examples: The farmer learned to butcher chickens for the market
They butcher their own livestock on the farm
The actor completely butchered his lines during the performance
Don't let him butcher that beautiful song

definitions: hit or push something with the head or horns forcefully
examples: The goat will butt anyone who comes too close
He butted his head against the door in frustration

definitions: spread butter on bread or other food to add flavor and moisture
examples: Please butter the toast while it's still warm
She carefully buttered each slice of bread for sandwiches

definitions: swim using the butterfly stroke with both arms moving together overhead
examples: She can butterfly faster than anyone on the swim team
Learning to butterfly properly takes considerable practice and strength

definitions: fasten clothing or fabric by pushing buttons through buttonholes
examples: Button your coat before going outside in the cold
The child is learning to button his shirt by himself

definitions: get something by paying money for it in a store or market
examples: I need to buy groceries for dinner tonight
They saved money to buy their first house

definitions: make a low continuous humming sound like a bee or electrical device
be filled with excitement activity or energetic conversation
examples: Bees buzz around the flower garden all day
The old fluorescent light buzzes when you turn it on
The office was buzzing with rumors about the merger
The crowd buzzed with anticipation before the concert

definitions: travel somewhere by taxi paying for the transportation service
examples: We decided to cab to the airport instead of driving
They cabbed around the city visiting tourist attractions

definitions: plot or scheme secretly with others against someone or something
examples: The ministers caballed against the unpopular policy
They were accused of caballing to overthrow the government

definitions: confine someone or something in a small enclosed space like a cabin
examples: The storm cabined us indoors for three days
They were cabined together in the tiny mountain shelter

definitions: send a message or communication through underwater telegraph cables
examples: They cabled the news to headquarters immediately
The reporter cabled his story from the war zone

definitions: hide or store something in a secret place for future use
examples: Squirrels cache nuts for the winter months ahead
The hikers cached supplies along their planned route

definitions: carry a golfer's clubs and give advice during a golf game
examples: He caddied for professional golfers during summer vacation
She learned to caddie at the local country club

definitions: carry a golfer's clubs and give advice during a golf game
examples: He caddied for professional golfers during summer vacation
She learned to caddy at the local country club

definitions: put an animal or bird in a cage to confine or imprison it
examples: They had to cage the wild bird until it healed
The zoo cages dangerous animals for visitor safety

definitions: form into a hard solid mass or layer through drying or compression
examples: Mud caked on his boots after the rainy hike
The blood had caked around the wound overnight

definitions: work out a number or amount using mathematics or arithmetic
plan something carefully considering all factors to achieve a goal
examples: Calculate the total cost before making the purchase
Scientists calculate the distance between stars using special formulas
She calculated every move to win the chess game
Politicians often calculate their words to appeal to voters

definitions: enter or schedule an event appointment or deadline on a calendar
examples: Please calendar our meeting for next Tuesday afternoon
She calendared all the important dates at the beginning

definitions: adjust an instrument or device to ensure accurate measurements or performance
examples: The technician needs to calibrate the scale every month
They calibrate the telescope before each observation session

definitions: measure the distance or thickness of something using caliper instruments
examples: The engineer calipered the pipe to ensure proper fit
She calipered each piece to maintain quality standards

definitions: speak loudly to get someone's attention or summon them
contact someone by telephone to have a conversation
give a name to something or describe it in a particular way
examples: Call the children inside for dinner please
She called his name across the crowded room
I'll call you tomorrow to discuss the details
He calls his mother every Sunday afternoon
They decided to call their baby daughter Emma
I wouldn't call this weather warm exactly

definitions: make someone emotionally hardened and insensitive through repeated exposure to hardship
examples: Years of rejection had calloused him against criticism
War can callous even the most sensitive people

definitions: make someone or something peaceful quiet and free from disturbance or strong emotion
examples: The mother calmed her crying baby with gentle rocking
Deep breathing exercises help calm anxious thoughts

definitions: build or shape something with a slight curve or arch especially roads
examples: Engineers camber roads to help water drain properly
The carpenter cambered the deck to prevent puddles

definitions: hide something by making it look like its surroundings using colors patterns or coverings
examples: Soldiers camouflage themselves with paint and leaves
The moth's wings camouflage it against tree bark

definitions: stay somewhere temporarily in a tent or simple shelter outdoors
behave in an exaggerated theatrical way often for humorous effect
examples: We love to camp by the lake every summer
The protesters camped outside city hall for weeks
The actor really camped it up in that comedy role
He tends to camp when telling stories at parties

definitions: work in an organized way toward a particular goal especially in politics or social issues
examples: She campaigned tirelessly for environmental protection laws
The senator will campaign across the state next month

definitions: preserve food by sealing it in metal or glass containers
dismiss someone from their job or position terminating employment
examples: My grandmother cans tomatoes from her garden every fall
The factory cans thousands of fish daily
The company canned half their staff during the recession
He got canned for repeatedly arriving late

definitions: create or dig an artificial waterway for boats or irrigation
examples: They plan to canal through the property for drainage
Ancient civilizations canaled water to their crops

definitions: decide that something planned will not happen and officially stop it
examples: We had to cancel our vacation due to illness
The school canceled classes because of the snowstorm

definitions: examine eggs by holding them up to light to check freshness or development
examples: Farmers candle eggs to ensure quality before selling
She learned to candle eggs at the poultry farm

definitions: preserve or coat fruit or other food with sugar syrup until crystallized
examples: She likes to candy orange peels for holiday treats
They candy ginger to make a sweet spicy snack

definitions: beat or punish someone with a stick made from cane
examples: Schools no longer cane students for misbehavior
In the past teachers would cane pupils for poor grades

definitions: become infected with sores or decay spreading corruption through tissue
examples: The wound began to canker without proper treatment
Jealousy can canker the heart like a disease

definitions: collide with something or someone forcefully at high speed
examples: The runaway cart cannoned into the wall
Players cannoned into each other during the game

definitions: travel on water in a narrow lightweight boat using paddles
examples: They love to canoe down peaceful rivers on weekends
We canoed across the lake to reach the island

definitions: cover something with an overhead shelter or decorative cloth covering
examples: Trees canopy the path providing welcome shade
They canopied the outdoor wedding area with white fabric

definitions: tilt or lean something at an angle from the vertical position
examples: The ship canted dangerously in the storm
He canted his chair back against the wall

definitions: ride a horse at a pace faster than trot but slower than gallop
examples: She cantered around the field enjoying the morning ride
The horses canter gracefully during the show

definitions: extend a structure horizontally beyond its vertical support like a projecting beam
examples: The architect cantilevered the deck over the hillside
They cantilevered the balcony to maximize the view

definitions: set an upper limit on something like spending or numbers
put a covering on top of something to close or protect it
examples: The government plans to cap rent increases at five percent
They need to cap spending to balance the budget
Cap the bottle tightly to keep it fresh
Snow caps the mountain peaks year round

definitions: skip or dance about in a lively playful way showing joy
examples: Children caper around the playground during recess
The lambs capered in the spring meadow

definitions: use something to your advantage making the most of an opportunity
write a letter or word with a capital letter at the beginning
examples: Smart businesses capitalise on new market trends quickly
She capitalised on her opponent's mistake to win
Remember to capitalise names and the beginning of sentences
You should capitalise all proper nouns in English
